description:
Humanity is exceeding the planetary boundary for nitrogen. Changing course will depend, in part, on how current and future smallholders manage nitrogen. Precision agriculture could play a key role but only if accompanied by policy reforms and investments that address a range of barriers to improved nitrogen management.
Smallholder farming systems (defined here as farms under 2 ha) are a linchpin of global food production. They represent 84% of farming households, chiefly in the developing world, and are responsible for approximately 30% of total crop production on 24% of agricultural land. 1,2 How nitrogen (N), an essential agricultural input, is managed in these systems over the coming decades will determine whether humanity can return to the N planetary boundary—a level of human interference beyond which damage to
ecosystems and human health could increase dramatically, perhaps permanently. Currently, the N planetary boundary is one of only two we are clearly exceeding; the other is biodiversity loss. The impacts of N loss to the environment are many and varied: losses of ammonia and N oxides contribute to air pollution, nitrate run-off stimulates eutrophication dead zones, and nitrous oxide emissions
exacerbate climate change and stratospheric ozone depletion. As a result, smallholder N management is at the core of several Sustainable Development Goals—from ending hunger to protecting life on land and taking serious action on climate change.
Better synchronizing N supply and demand in smallholder systems would meet all Climate Smart Agriculture objectives—less excess N could reduce nitrous oxide emissions, one of the most important agricultural greenhouse gases; more targeted N application could increase yields; and reducing farmer N costs viamore efficient application techniques would increase both net income and resilience to various shocks, including spikes in fertilizer price.
name: Precision Agriculture for Smallholder Nitrogen Management
